issues.title: NIT: Replace NULL with NUL
issues.author: xorrkaz
issues.body: In Section 2.1, the text refers to padding Object Payload with NULL characters if it does not end on a 32-bit boundary.  I think this should read "NUL bytes" or "NUL characters" instead.

issues.title: Adjust interface name and index references
issues.author: xorrkaz
issues.body:
This document refers to the ietf-interfaces.yang module when making reference to an interface's name and index.  Section 2.1 states:

>If the Interface Identification Object identifies the probed interface by index, the length is equal to 8 and the payload contains the if-index [[RFC8343](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8343)].

However, in other parts of the document, the older MIB names of ifName and ifIndex are used.  It would be clearer if the referenced YANG module names were used throughout.

That is, in Section 4, replace ifName with name and ifIndex with if-index (these match the referred RFC).  And in Section 7 (if it stays in the final document), replace ifName with name.

issues.title: Limit the address families used
issues.author: xorrkaz
issues.body:
This document describes that when the L bit is not set, one can specify an interface address using:

>All values found in the IANA registry of Address Family Numbers (available from [[IANA.address-family-numbers](http://www.iana.org/assignments/address-family-numbers)]) are valid in this field.

However, in Section 1, it is mentioned that resolution for a non-local address will be done using either ARP or NDP table lookups.  While IPv4, IPv6, and MAC can be found in these tables, other AFIs may not be.  As such, I think the text should be limited to AFIs for IPv4, IPv6, and 48-bit MAC alone.  Any other AFI would result in a malformed message as the lookup cannot be performed.  

Alternatively, if other lookups could be supported, that could be described here or simply left for other extension documents that might update this document.

comments.author: fenner
comments.body:
Thanks for bringing this up, Joe.  [Section 4.1](https://fenner.github.io/probe-clarification/draft-fenner-intarea-probe-clarification.html#name-code-field-processing) says:

> The Code field MUST be set to (3) No Such Table Entry if the L-bit
> is clear and the address found in the Interface Identification Object
> does not appear in the IPv4 Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) table or
> the IPv6 Neighbor Cache.

In my mind, this is sufficient - if you set the AF to IPX, and that IPX address doesn't appear in the IPv4 ARP or IPv6 neighbor cache (hint: it can't), then you return No Such Table Entry - so we have a well defined behavior in the "arbitrary AF" case.

If we try to go down the path of limiting this in the address field specification, we end up having to differentiate based on the setting of the L bit - since it's actually valid to ask about the interface with IPX address foo if L=1.

comments.author: xorrkaz
comments.body: I think the "No Such Table Entry" error is fine in this case.

issues.title: Update IANA Considerations
issues.author: fenner
issues.body:
IANA's pre-meeting review for IETF120 included:

The actions described in the IANA Considerations section were completed for RFC 8335. Should IANA replace references to RFC 8355 with references to this document? If so, please add a sentence to the beginning of the section that instructs us to do so. If not, please update the section to note that no IANA actions are required (and move the 8335 actions to another section, if possible).

issues.title: Leave the door open to a different packet format if a different extension object is present
issues.author: fenner
issues.body:
From Ron:
> Currently, RFC 8335 says that the Extended Echo Request MUST contain exactly one instance of the Interface Identifier Object.  I would like to replace that text with the following:

> "The Extended Echo Request message MUST contain zero or one instances of the Interface Identification Object. If the Interface Identification Object is absent, the probed interface is identified by Destination Address in the IP header".

> This change will allow us to reuse the Extended Echo Request and Extended Echo Reply message in another application (Loopback 6)

comments.author: fenner
comments.body:
My proposal to be a little less proscriptive, something like

> “Extended Echo contains an ICMP Extension structure that defines the operation to perform. When it contains the Echo Request, it MUST … The behavior when it contains a different extension object is not defined by this memo but may be defined in the future”
